revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox university | name = Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science | native_name = | image_name = RSMAS-Logo.png | image_size = 200px | image_alt = The Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science's logo | caption = The Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science's logo | latin_name = | motto = | mottoeng = | established = 1943 | closed = | type = | affiliation = | endowment = | officer_in_charge = | chairman = | chancellor = | president = | vice-president = | superintendent = | provost = | vice_chancellor = | rector = | principal = | dean = Roni Avissar | director = | head_label = | head = | faculty = 90 | staff = | students = | undergrad = 400 | postgrad = 220 | doctoral = | other = | city = [[Virginia Key]], [[Miami]] | state = [[Florida]] | province = | country = USA | coor = {{coord|25.732479|-80.163245|region:US_type:edu|display=title}} | campus = Urban | former_names = UM Marine Lab | free_label = | free = | sports = | colors = | nickname = | mascot = | athletics = | affiliations = | website = [http://rsmas.miami.edu www.rsmas.miami.edu] | logo = }}
The '''Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science''' ('''RSMAS''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|r|æ|z|.|m|ə|s}}) is a academic and research institution for the study of [[oceanography]] and the [[atmospheric sciences]] within the [[University of Miami]] (UM). It is located on a 16 [[acre]] (65,000 m²) campus on [[Virginia Key]] in [[Miami, Florida|Miami]], [[Florida]]. It is the only subtropical applied and basic marine and atmospheric research institute in the continental United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.underwatertimes.com/ref/ref.php|title=The Reference Desk|accessdate=February 18, 2010|publisher=UnderwaterTimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://marinesciencetoday.com/2009/07/17/university-roundup-rosentstiel-school-of-marine-and-atmospheric-science-at-the-university-of-miami/|publisher=Marine Science Today|title=University Roundup: Rosentstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science at the University of Miami|accessdate=2011-04-16}}</ref>
Up until 2008, RSMAS was solely a [[graduate school]] within the University of Miami, while it jointly administrated an [[undergraduate education|undergraduate program]] with UM's College of Arts and Sciences. In 2008, the Rosenstiel School has taken over administrative responsibilities for the undergraduate program, granting Bachelor of Science in Marine and Atmospheric Science (BSMAS) and Bachelor of Arts in Marine Affairs (BAMA) [[baccalaureate degree]]. [[master's degree|Master's]], including a Master of [[First professional degree|Professional]] Science degree, and [[Doctor of Philosophy|doctorates]] are also awarded to RSMAS students by the UM Graduate School.<ref name=mps>{{cite web|url=http://mps.rsmas.miami.edu/|title=Master of Professional Science - Rosenstiel School of Marine & Atmospheric Science - University of Miami|accessdate=February 2, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.miami.edu/gs/index.php/graduate_school/about_us/message_from_the_dean/|title=Message from the Dean {{!}} Graduate School {{!}} University of Miami|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=2011-02-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720000147/http://www.miami.edu/gs/index.php/graduate_school/about_us/message_from_the_dean/|archivedate=2011-07-20|df=}}</ref>
The Rosenstiel School's research includes the [[marine biology|study of marine life]], particularly ''[[Aplysia]]'' and [[coral]]; [[climate change]]; air-sea interactions; [[coastal ecology]]; and [[admiralty law]]. The school operates a marine research laboratory ship, and has a research site at an inland [[sinkhole]]. Research also includes the use of data from weather satellites and the school operates its own satellite downlink facility.
==History== [[Image:Rosenstiel Entrance Plate.jpg|thumb|left|The sign near the entrance to RSMAS.]]
In 1940, University of Miami President Bowman Ashe recruited [[F.G. Walton Smith]], a young British marine biologist who was working in the Bahamas. Smith joined the Department of Zoology, and began organizing the development of a marine laboratory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/about-rsmas/history/|title=The History of the Rosenstiel School of Marine & Atmospheric Science|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=April 12, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525183106/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/about-rsmas/history/|archive-date=2011-05-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> In 1943, the Board of Trustees of the University of Miami established the Marine Laboratory for the University.<ref name=hist/> They invited researchers and oceanographers to associate themselves with this laboratory. Its three original objectives were teaching, basic research, and applied marine research. The laboratory focused on subjects specific to the tropical environment. Initially, the Marine Lab was located in a private boathouse on an estate on Belle Isle in [[Miami Beach, Florida]]. In 1945, when the boathouse became structurally unsafe, the lab moved to a converted apartment building in [[Coral Gables, Florida]] near the main campus.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/about-rsmas/history/|title=The History of the Rosenstiel School of Marine & Atmospheric Science|first=Jean|last=Yehle|work=www.rsmas.miami.edu|accessdate=2011-04-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525183106/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/about-rsmas/history/|archive-date=2011-05-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
In 1947, a delegation from [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Dade County]] prompted the [[Florida State Legislature]] to support the development of a state Marine Laboratory in conjunction with the UM lab. It reported to the [[Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission|State Board of Conservation]], which had no marine research facility and little budget of its own at the time.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AGQpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KMgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3195,6215129&dq=florida+marine+laboratory&hl=en|title=State Adds $25,000 in Tide Fight|work=Daytona Beach Morning Journal |date=January 27, 1954|page=5|quote=The Legislature appropriated $80,000 per year for research work and specified that it be paid from shell revenues.|accessdate=February 28, 2011}}</ref> The relationship lasted for 12 years until the state of Florida built the board a lab in [[St. Petersburg, Florida|St. Petersburg]]. In 1953, the School's classrooms and laboratories were built at the current Virginia Key location. It was renamed the Institute of Marine Science in 1961,<ref name=hist>{{cite web|title=Dorothy H. and Lewis Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science|url=http://www6.miami.edu/umbulletin/und/marine/index.htm|accessdate=November 13, 2007}}</ref> it became part of the University of Miami's School of Environmental and Planetary Sciences.<ref>{{cite web|title=Semiannual Status Report NASA GRANT NGR-10-007-010|date=October 31, 1966|url= https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19670082520_1967082520.pdf|publisher=NASA|accessdate=November 13, 2007}}</ref>
In 1969, the institution was made into an independent school and named to honor [[Lewis Rosenstiel|Lewis and Dorothy Rosenstiel]] after a major contribution from the Rosenstiel's foundation to support progress in atmospheric and marine sciences. In 1977, the school began a joint undergraduate program with Miami's College of Arts & Sciences.<ref name=msc/> The school bought Research vessels and built more facilities to further research projects. From 2003 to 2008, the school operated the Pew Institute for Ocean Science as a joint venture with the [[Pew Charitable Trusts]], and in 2008, the program relocated to [[SUNY at Stony Brook]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aafcseafood.org/Documents/conquest_of_the_ocean.pdf|title=Conquest of the Ocean|accessdate=November 15, 2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Stony Brook Southampton Broadens Scope With Ocean Conservation Institute|url=http://www.hamptons.com/detail.php?articleID=4646|first=Kelly |last=Carroll|work=hamptons.com|accessdate=November 15, 2010}}</ref>
In 2008, RSMAS took over administrative functions of the University of Miami's undergraduate Marine Science, Marine Affairs, and Meteorology programs.<ref name="msc">{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/pressreleases/20080820-rsmas.html|title=University of Miami’s Rosenstiel School Prepares to Launch Historic Academic Year|accessdate=October 17, 2008|date=August 20, 2008|publisher=University of Miami|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122033210/http://rsmas.miami.edu/pressreleases/20080820-rsmas.html|archive-date=2008-11-22|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www6.miami.edu/umbulletin/pdf/RSMASGrad201011.pdf|title=Dorothy H. and Lewis Rosentiel School Of Marine And Atmospheric Science - Graduate|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=February 28, 2011}}</ref> Also in 2008, RSMAS's library merged with the central University of Miami Library.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/info/2008_Annual_Report.pdf|title=2008 Rosenstiel Annual Report|page=1|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=February 2, 2011|archivedate=July 23, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100723105857/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/info/2008_Annual_Report.pdf|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Recently, RSMAS started unique a one-year Master of Professional Science degree program aimed at students planning non-research careers in business, government, or non-profit organizations.<ref name=mps /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mps.rsmas.miami.edu/about/|title=About the Program|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=April 14, 2011}}</ref>
==Academics== [[Image:Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science Courtyard.jpg|thumb|Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science's courtyard, with the Grosvenor Building on the left.]]
While the graduate programs are conducted by the RSMAS faculty who in turn report to the Dean of RSMAS, the University of Miami's Graduate School awards the graduate degrees.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www6.miami.edu/umbulletin/grad/gradschool/index.htm|title=Graduate School|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=2010-02-13}}</ref> RSMAS offers a joint program with the UM Law School which awards its students both a [[Juris Doctor]] degree and a Master of Arts in Marine Affairs and Policy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www6.miami.edu/umbulletin/grad/marine/index.htm|title=Marine and Atmospheric Science Program - Graduate|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=February 13, 2010}}</ref> RSMAS also administrates the University of Miami's undergraduate Marine Science, Marine Affairs, and Meteorology programs on the main campus in [[Coral Gables, Florida]].<ref name="msc"/>
The Rosenstiel School is divided into six academic divisions, each focusing on a different aspect of oceanography: * Ocean Sciences ([[fluid dynamics]], [[remote sensing]], [[wave]]s)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/academics/divisions/applied-marine-physics|title=Applied Marine Physics|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=November 15, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110215105254/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/academics/divisions/applied-marine-physics/|archivedate=February 15, 2011|df=}}</ref> * Marine Ecosystem and Society ([[admiralty law]], [[aquaculture]], [[marine conservation]], [[maritime archaeology]], [[natural resource economics]], [[political ecology]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/academics/divisions/marine-affairs-policy|title=Marine Affairs and Policy|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=November 15, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110205152506/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/academics/divisions/marine-affairs-policy//|archivedate=February 5, 2011|df=}}</ref> * [[Marine Biology]] & [[Fisheries science|Ecology]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/academics/divisions/marine-biology-fisheries|title=Marine Biology & Fisheries|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=November 15, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110205152624/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/academics/divisions/marine-biology-fisheries//|archivedate=February 5, 2011|df=}}</ref> * [[marine geology|Marine G]][[Geophysics|eosciences]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/academics/divisions/marine-geology-geophysics|title=Marine Geology and Geophysics|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=November 15, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110128090253/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/academics/divisions/marine-geology-geophysics/|archivedate=January 28, 2011|df=}}</ref> * Atmospheric Sciences<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/academics/divisions/meteorology-physical-oceanography|title=Meteorology and Physical Oceanography|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=November 15, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110205152656/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/academics/divisions/meteorology-physical-oceanography//|archivedate=February 5, 2011|df=}}</ref>
In addition to the academic divisions, RSMAS also has several research units: the Oceans and Human Health Center, the National Resource for ''[[Aplysia]]'', the National Center for Coral Reef Research, the [[Center for Southeastern Tropical Advanced Remote Sensing]] (CSTARS), and the [[National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences]]. {{As of|2011}}, 358 professors and scientists conduct research programs and teach at RSMAS and the Coral Gables campus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.miami.edu/planning-research/FBFA2010.pdf|title=Fall 2010 Fact Book|publisher=University of Miami Office of Planning, Institutional Research & Assessment|page=125|accessdate=February 2, 2011}}</ref> Of these, 81 are regular full-time faculty members.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.miami.edu/planning-research/FBFA2010.pdf|title=Fall 2010 Fact Book|publisher=University of Miami Office of Planning, Institutional Research & Assessment|page=122|accessdate=February 2, 2011}}</ref>
The school operates the ''F.G. Walton Smith'' [[research vessel]]. Designed to met the school's specifications, the [[catamaran]] was put on water in 2000. It is equipped with a special sea water flow system that can take samples. The on-board lab can perform chemical analysis of those water samples. It also has [[transducer]]s for measuring ocean currents, sub-bottom profiling, and deep water [[bathymetry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/support/mardep/cat/FGWSBrochure.pdf|title=F. G. Walton Smith|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=November 15, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100623225335/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/support/mardep/cat/FGWSBrochure.pdf|archivedate=June 23, 2010|df=}}</ref> In response to the [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill]], the vessel was reassigned to environmental monitoring of affected areas and to track underwater plumes of oil.<ref name=oilspillpr/><!--<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/oil-spill/media/good-morning-america-20100602.html|title=Good Morning America|work=ABC News|date=June 2, 2010|accessdate=November 15, 2010}}</ref>--><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/video/researcher-undiscovered-plumes-10765803|title=Web Extra: Scientist's Gulf Report |date=May 27, 2010|accessdate=April 14, 2011|publisher=ABC News}}</ref>
The Rosenstiel School's research invertebrate museum houses one of the world's most extensive collections of invertebrate tropical marine life with 400,000 specimens. It includes Atlantic tropical marine invertebrates. The collection consists of 60,000 specimen lots, out of which 38,900 are cataloged and identified species.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/resources/invertebrate-museum/|title=Invertebrate Museum|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=April 14, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517211735/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/resources/invertebrate-museum/|archive-date=2011-05-17|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
Since 2005, RSMAS has conducted an [[underwater photography]] contest that draws international submissions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.innovations-report.com/html/reports/awards_funding/2010_underwater_photography_contest_winners_155441.html|title=2010 Underwater Photography Contest Winners Announced|publisher=innovations-report|date=May 28, 2010|accessdate=November 15, 2010}}</ref> RSMAS also makes underwater photographs available through its Digital Atlas of Marine Species and Locations, which is a database that includes photos of specific marine species.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://damsl.org/|title=Digital Atlas of Marine Species and Locations|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=November 15, 2010}}</ref>
Since 1951, RSMAS has published the ''Bulletin of Marine Science'' a [[scientific journal]] which publishes research papers in the marine subject areas covered by the school. It is published four times a year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/bms/|title=Bulletin of Marine Science|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=November 15, 2010}}</ref>
The [[United States National Research Council]] ranked graduate research programs based on 2008 data, and RSMAS ranked 11th to 40th among Oceanography, Atmospheric Sciences, and Meteorology Rankings. The RSMAS entering graduate students' Average Quantitative [[Graduate Record Examination]] score was 681.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://graduate-school.phds.org/university/miami/program/ranking/oceanography/5763|title=Program Rankings — Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science, University of Miami|publisher=PhDs.org Student Guide Collected Insight, Inc.|accessdate=February 2, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125080746/http://graduate-school.phds.org/university/miami/program/ranking/oceanography/5763|archivedate=November 25, 2010|df=}}</ref>
==Campus== [[Image:Rosenstiel Applied Marine Physics Building.jpg|thumb|left|RSMAS's Marine Science Center]] The Virginia Key {{convert|18|acre|m2|adj=on}} campus includes classroom facilities, laboratories, a [[Dock (maritime)|dock]], and a student center. The center, called the F. G. Walton Smith Commons, holds a cafeteria and a bar (aka "the wet lab") that was rated as one of Miami's best secrets by the ''[[Miami New Times]]'' in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.miaminewtimes.com/bestof/2008/award/best-secret-1006243/|title=The bar at the Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences|year=2008|publisher=Miami New Times|accessdate=February 2, 2011}}</ref> The RSMAS campus features [[mangrove]]s, [[Coccoloba uvifera|sea grape]] trees, and other dune plants to protect its sand dunes and the campus from storm damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/outreach/explore-and-discover/go-green/on-campus/mangrove-restoration/|title=Green: Mangroves Restoration|publisher=The Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science at the University of Miami|accessdate=February 2, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110308014549/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/outreach/explore-and-discover/go-green/on-campus/mangrove-restoration/|archive-date=March 8, 2011|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 2009, UM received a $15 million federal grant to help construct a new $43.8 million, {{convert|56500|sqft|m2}} Marine Technology and Life Sciences Seawater Research Building.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/southflorida/stories/2009/07/20/daily10.html|title=UM marine science school awarded $15M in stimulus|date=July 20, 2009|work=South Florida Business Journal|first=Brian|last=Bandell|accessdate=February 7, 2010}}</ref> The Virginia Key campus is located at a {{convert|65|acre|m2|adj=on}} marine research and education park that is also home to two [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] (NOAA) research laboratories and the [[MAST Academy|Maritime and Science Technology Academy]] [[magnet school]].<ref name=campus/>
RSMAS also operates a {{convert|76|acre|m2|adj=on}} site on mainland Miami-Dade County that was formerly the [[United States Naval Observatory]] Secondary National Time Standard Facility, which already had buildings and a 20M antenna used for [[Very Long Baseline Interferometry]] (VLBI).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www6.miami.edu/research/10oct2002.pdf|title=University of Miami|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=November 21, 2009}}</ref> The Rosenstiel School's Center for Southeastern Tropical Advanced Remote Sensing (CSTARS) and Richmond Satellite Operations Center (RSOC) have research facilities located on what is now named the Richmond Campus.<ref name=campus>{{cite web|url=http://www.miami.edu/index.php/about_us/campuses_and_facilities/|title=Campuses and Facilities|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=February 2, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091106215017/http://www.miami.edu/index.php/about_us/campuses_and_facilities/|archivedate=November 6, 2009|df=}}</ref>
==Research== [[Image:V F.G. Walton Smith.JPG|thumb|The ''R/V F.G. Walton Smith'', a [[research vessel|research]] [[catamaran]] utilized by RSMAS.]] As of 2008, RSMAS receives $50 million in annual external research funding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/info/2008_Annual_Report.pdf|title=2008 Rosenstiel Annual Report|page=30|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=November 21, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091116212203/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/info/2008_Annual_Report.pdf|archivedate=November 16, 2009|df=}}</ref> Laboratories at Virginia Key are equipped with specialized instruments including a salt-water wave tank, the five-tank Conditioning and Spawning Systems, multi-tank ''[[Aplysia]]'' Culture Laboratory, Controlled Corals Climate Tanks, and DNA analysis equipment. The Richmond Campus' CSTARS provides RSMAS with a near-real-time weather satellite downlink. The Rosenstiel School also operates the Bimini Biological Field Station,<ref name=bimini>{{cite web|url=http://www6.miami.edu/sharklab/|title=Bimini Biological Field Station|publisher=Bimini Biological Field Station|year=2004|accessdate=February 2, 2011}}</ref> an array of oceanographic high-frequency radar along the US east coast, and the Bermuda aerosol observatory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/research/facilities.html |title=Rosenstiel School Facilities |publisher=University of Miami |accessdate=November 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090830081024/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/research/facilities.html |archivedate=August 30, 2009 }}</ref> Since 1977, the Cooperative Institute for Marine and Atmospheric Studies (CIMAS), a scientific partnership between UM and the NOAA, has been studying climate change, air-sea interactions and coastal ecology.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/info/2008_Annual_Report.pdf|title=2008 Rosenstiel Annual Report|page=17|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=November 21, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091116212203/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/info/2008_Annual_Report.pdf|archivedate=November 16, 2009|df=}}</ref>
Research projects at RSMAS are in the domain of atmospheric and marine sciences and include:
*Coral reef research, focusing on corals survival in a new climate conditions; [[coral reef protection]] *Field programs evaluating trace gas chemistry and transport *The aquaculture program *Climate change modeling *Tropical weather, climate, and atmospheric/oceanic circulations *Air-sea interactions research through buoys, remote sensing, analysis in situ, a wave tank laboratory, numerical modeling; *Volcanoes in the Pacific, Everglades water level measurements and subsidence through satellite images *Studies of the coastal quality and the impact on human health.
[[File:Little Salt Spring NASA.jpg|thumb|A satellite photo of [[Little Salt Spring]]. The field laboratory and dormitories are left of center; the dock over the water is used by [[technical diving|research divers]] when [[Underwater archaeology|excavating]].]] RSMAS's Marine Affairs & Policy Division also conducts [[archaeology|archaeological]] and [[paleontology|paleontological]] research at [[Little Salt Spring]] in [[Sarasota County, Florida|Sarasota County]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www6.miami.edu/UMH/CDA/UMH_Main/0,1770,2593-1;39289-3,00.html |title=Little Salt Spring Reveals More Florida History |date=July 6, 2005 |accessdate=November 16, 2009 |publisher=University of Miami |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060922003500/http://www6.miami.edu/UMH/CDA/UMH_Main/0,1770,2593-1;39289-3,00.html |archivedate=September 22, 2006 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/203/4381/609|title=Little Salt Spring, Florida: A Unique Underwater Site|journal=Science|first=C. J. |last=Clausen|author2= A. D. Cohen|author3=Cesare Emiliani|author4=J. A. Holman|author5= J. J. Stipp|volume=203|issue=4381|pages=609–614|doi=10.1126/science.203.4381.609|date=16 February 1979|accessdate=February 5, 2010|publisher=[[Science (journal)|Science]]|pmid=17813360}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Holocene paleohydrology of Little Salt Spring, Florida, based on ostracod assemblages and stable isotopes|first=Carlos A. |last=Alvarez Zarikiana|author2=Peter K. Swart|author3=John A. Gifford|author4=Patricia L. Blackwelder|doi=10.1016/j.palaeo.2004.01.023|journal=Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology|date=5 August 2005|volume=225|issue=1–4|pages=134–156}}</ref> The site was donated to the University of Miami in 1982.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.themiamihurricane.com/2009/02/25/little-salt-spring-makes-big-news-nationwide/|title=Little Salt Spring makes big news nationwide|work=Miami Hurricane|date=February 25, 2009|first=Ashleigh |last=Maynard|accessdate=February 5, 2010}}</ref> RSMAS also hosts the National Center for Coral Reef Research (NCORE), which works to understand, conserve and manage coral reefs worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncore.rsmas.miami.edu/|title=NCORE Home Page|publisher=University of Miami|accessdate=November 14, 2010}}</ref>
RSMAS has focused significant resources to studying the Deepwater Horizon oil spill and its long term environmental effect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/oil-spill/ |title=The Rosenstiel School - Oil Spill |publisher=University of Miami |accessdate=November 17, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130129001535/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/oil-spill/ |archivedate=January 29, 2013 }}</ref> The school is an active member of the State of Florida's Oil Spill Academic Task Force that works with the [[Florida Department of Environmental Protection]] on spill issues.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oilspill.fsu.edu/index.php|title=State of Florida Oil Spill Academic Task Force|publisher=Florida State University|accessdate=April 14, 2011}}</ref> In the summer of 2010, a CIMAS team working with the research vessel Walton Smith was able to document a {{convert|23|mi|km|adj=on}} long oil plume extending toward the [[Dry Tortugas]].<ref name=oilspillpr>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/pressreleases/20100612-noaa.html|title=UM/CIMAS and NOAA/AOML Scientists Locate Oil Plume Extending Toward Dry Tortugas|publisher=University of Miami|date=June 12, 2010|accessdate=April 14, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101019101038/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/pressreleases/20100612-noaa.html|archive-date=2010-10-19|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
The quality of the school is evaluated through peer-reviewed competition for faculty research grants. In addition, each year, the National Science Foundation conduct a nationwide student competition for Graduate Research Award Fellowship, and in 2010, five RSMAS students received such awards with two additional honorable mentions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2010-08/uomr-fur081010.php|title=5 UM Rosenstiel School students receive NSF grad research grants|publisher=eurekalert.org|date=August 10, 2010|accessdate=November 15, 2010}}</ref>
==Notable faculty== * [[Frederick Bayer]] (Marine Biology)<ref name=bg>{{Cite news |first=Adam |last=Bernstein|title= Frederick Bayer, 85; biologist studied corals in deep sea |url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/obituaries/articles/2007/10/23/frederick_bayer_85_biologist_studied_corals_in_deep_sea/|work= [[Washington Post]] |publisher=[[Boston Globe]] |date=2007-10-23 |accessdate=October 23, 2007}}</ref> * [[Cesare Emiliani]] (Geology and Geophysics) - "founder of paleoceanography"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.websters-online-dictionary.org/definitions/Cesare?cx=partner-pub-0939450753529744%3Av0qd01-tdlq&cof=FORID%3A9&ie=UTF-8&q=Cesare&sa=Search#922|archive-date=September 15, 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120915101226/http://www.websters-online-dictionary.org/definitions/Cesare?cx=partner-pub-0939450753529744:v0qd01-tdlq&cof=FORID:9&ie=UTF-8&q=Cesare&sa=Search%23922#922|dead-url=yes|title=Definition of Cesare|publisher=Webster's Online Dictionary|accessdate=February 2, 2011}}</ref> * [[Samuel H. Gruber]] (Marine Biology and Fisheries)<ref name=bimini/> * [[José Carlos Millás]] (Meteorology)<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dpYzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=SusFAAAAIBAJ&pg=881,4816049 |title=Obituary: Dr. Jose Carlos Millas, Cuban Meteorologist |newspaper=[[The Miami News]] |date=November 29, 1965|accessdate=February 2, 2011 |postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> * [[Fred Tappert]] (Applied Marine Physics)
==See also== *[[List of University of Miami alumni]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== {{commons category|Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science}} *[http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/ University of Miami's Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science website]. *[http://damsl.org/ Digital Atlas of Marine Species and Locations] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100623225335/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/support/mardep/cat/FGWSBrochure.pdf F.G. Walton Smith vessel brochure] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20101117182552/http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/info/2010_RSMAS_brochure.pdf RSMAS brochure]
{{University of Miami}}

[[File:Rusty trombone simple.svg|thumb|150px|Simple illustration of heterosexual rusty trombone]] '''Rusty trombone''' is an act in which a man stands with his knees and back slightly [[torqued]] with feet at least shoulder width apart to expose his [[anus]].<ref name="dictionary">Tate, Jordan. (January 9, 2007) The Contemporary Dictionary of Sexual Euphemisms. Publisher [[St. Martin's Press]] {{ISBN|0-312-36298-6}}</ref> The "player" typically kneels behind the man and performs [[anilingus]] while reaching up beneath the [[testicle]]s or around the body to manually administer rapid up and down motions of the [[penis]], mimicking the motions of a [[trombone]] player.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="words">Sex Dictionary. (2007) ''[http://www.thesexdictionary.com/alphabet/r.shtml Sex Words Defined and Explained: R.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070717215007/http://www.thesexdictionary.com/alphabet/r.shtml |date=2007-07-17 }}''</ref> The act is defined primarily by the physical orientation of the partners, the combination of anilingus with manual [[sexual stimulation]] and the resemblance of the [[External anal sphincter|anal sphincter]] to a trombone mouthpiece; however, other positions and variations are possible.
==Usage history== In 2003, the [[Detroit, Michigan]] talk radio show [[Deminski & Doyle]] began an educational hour discussion of urban-legendary sex acts with the statement, "Try to describe carefully what a '[[Cleveland steamer]]' would be..." and then went into details of the [[blumpkin]] and the rusty trombone.<ref name="shock">[[Josh Walk|Wolk, Josh]]. (May 30, 2003) ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''. ''[http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,454147,00.html State Of Shock: Day after day, from sea to shining sea, America's SHOCK JOCKS manage to shtick it where the FCC don't shine.] "and then proceeded to describe the wonders of the ''blumpkin'' and the ''rusty trombone.''"'' Section: No. 712.</ref> Fifteen months later, the [[Federal Communications Commission]] proposed a fine of $27,500 to the station's owner, [[Infinity Broadcasting]], through a Notice of Apparent Liability (NAL)<ref>[[Federal Communications Commission]] (April 3, 2003) ''[http://www.fcc.gov/eb/Orders/2003/FCC-03-71A1.html Notice of Apparent Liability (NAL).]'' ""Rusty Trombone," and again please, no kids, no women. "Rusty Trombone" I believe that's when you're having anal sex with a girl and then right afterwards you make her perform uh, oral sex on you." Obtained July 11, 2007.</ref> that specifically referenced rusty trombone.<ref name="shock"/>
Rusty trombone (dirty trombone) gained wider use in entertainment projects being developed for release in 2005. For example, comedian [[Andy Dick]] used the term in the 2005 [[documentary film]] ''[[The Aristocrats (film)|The Aristocrats]]'' as part of the infamous [[dirty joke]] of the [[The Aristocrats (joke)|same name]].<ref name="telegraph">Sooke, Alastair. (August 19, 2005) [[The Daily Telegraph]]. ''[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2005/08/19/bfjoke19.xml&menuId=564&sSheet=/arts/2005/08/19/ixartleft.html Want to hear the world's dirtiest joke?]'' "While the comics riff about incest, Shetland ponies, oral sex with armadillos and rusty trombones (don't ask), the cornucopia of smut inures you to its own excess." Section: Features; Page 21.</ref> In seeming recognition of the phrase being a part of the filthiest of filthy language, news sources such as [[The Daily Telegraph]],<ref name="telegraph"/> [[Slant Magazine]],<ref>Schager, Nick. (2005) [[Slant Magazine]]. ''[http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/film_review.asp?ID=1632 Film Review: The Aristocrats.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060908085547/http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/film_review.asp?ID=1632 |date=2006-09-08 }}''</ref> [[New Statesman]],<ref>[[Rosie Millard|Millard, Rosie]]. (August 22, 2005) ''[[New Statesman]]''. Singer, model and television personality [[Tila Tequila]] can be seen performing a rusty trombone in her sex tape released in 2008. ''[http://www.newstatesman.com/200508220032 Notebook: Comics tell each other the rudest - and most secret - joke in the world after the audience has left.]'' Volume 18; Issue 873; Page 31.</ref> and ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' highlighted rusty trombone in their review of ''[[The Aristocrats (film)|The Aristocrats]]''. In addition, in the 2005 movie ''[[The 40-Year-Old Virgin]]''.<ref>Walton, Rob. (August 2005) [[Playboy Online]]. ''[http://www.playboy.com/arts-entertainment/reviews/movies/40yearoldvirgin/ Movie Review Of 40 Year Old Virgin.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070204121627/http://www.playboy.com/arts-entertainment/reviews/movies/40yearoldvirgin/ |date=2007-02-04 }}''</ref> the character Mooj stated, "It's not about these rusty trombones, and these [[dirty sanchez (sexual act)|dirty sanchez]]."<ref>[[Internet Movie Database]]. ''[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0405422/quotes The 40 Year Old Virgin (2005) - Memorable quotes.]'' Access date: February 8, 2007.</ref> In the film ''[[Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny]]'', actor [[Jack Black]] is seen in walking around the [[Venice Beach]], [[California]] boardwalk in a Rusty Trombone T-shirt.<ref>Purlky Jr., Jordy "Ray". (December 1, 2006) [[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]. ''[http://www.accessatlanta.com/blogs/content/shared-blogs/accessatlanta/movies/entries/2006/12/01/jack_black_also.html Jack Black also lives on that street of dreams.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928015401/http://www.accessatlanta.com/blogs/content/shared-blogs/accessatlanta/movies/entries/2006/12/01/jack_black_also.html |date=2007-09-28 }}'' Section: Movies & More; Page 6.</ref>
Rusty trombone is part of the 2006 party game PervArtistry, where individuals draw sexual pictures on a board and other players try to guess the sexual synonym for that image.<ref>[[Tristan Taormino|Taormino, Tristan]]. (May 3, 2006) [[The Village Voice]]. ''[http://www.villagevoice.com/people/0618,taormino,73044,24.html Lexicon of lust: West village bar hosts a game for pervy wordsmiths.]'' Volume 51; Issue 18; Page 129.</ref>
In 2007, [[Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]] activist David Nelson started an online petition calling for the repeal of Utah's existing [[sodomy law]].<ref name="guns">Burt, Brandon. (January 18, 2007) [[Salt Lake City Weekly]] ''[http://www.slweekly.com/index.cfm?oID=449BBE6E-021E-D69E-7A3370304BA7D31B&do=article.details&id=1CB73541-2BF4-55D0-F1F9684618053C73 Guns and Butt Sex.]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}'' Volume 23; Issue 35; Page 10. Obtained July 12, 2007.)</ref> Reportedly, Utah's existing sodomy law prohibits [[oral sex]], [[anal sex]], and the rusty trombone.<ref name="guns"/>
Also in 2007, rusty trombone was listed along with AC/DC ([[sexual slang]] referring to [[bisexuality]], while it can also mean [[alternating current]]/[[direct current]]), [[Beverly Hillbilly]], and [[Sugar in the Shoes]] as one of 76 entries in ''The Contemporary Dictionary of Sexual Euphemisms'' (2007), with both its literal definition and sexual corollary.<ref>Genovese, Peter. (March 4, 2007) [[The Star-Ledger]] ''Living smart: It's all in the details.'' Section:Accent; Page 8</ref>
In 2012, ''[[Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson|Late, Late Show]]'' host [[Craig Ferguson]] began a running gag offering guests the opportunity to play a rusty trombone. Viewers are assured that, as long as he shows the actual oxidized musical instrument, the CBS censors will not try to stop him. (March 4, 2013)
In 2013, during the final credits of ''[[Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa]]'', an extra scene shows Billy asking a mall [[Santa Claus]] for a "rusty trombone" for his grandpa. The full scene is featured in ''[[Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa .5]]''.
==See also== * [[Handjob]] * [[Oral sex]]
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References== * Tate, Jordan. (January 9, 2007) ''The Contemporary Dictionary of Sexual Euphemism''s. Publisher [[St. Martin's Press]] {{ISBN|0-312-36298-6}}
==External links== * {{Wiktionary-inline|rusty trombone|Rusty trombone}}
{{Sexual slang}}

revision.text:
[[File:Hawksbill turtle at Elphinstone Reef, Red Sea, Egypt (36522421716).jpg|thumb|[[Hawksbill sea turtle]], a spongivore]] A '''spongivore''' is an [[animal]] anatomically and physiologically adapted to eating animals of the [[phylum]] [[Porifera]], commonly called [[sea sponges]], for the main component of its diet. As a result of their diet, spongivore animals like the [[hawksbill turtle]] have developed sharp, narrow bird-like beak that allows them to reach within crevices on the reef to obtain sponges.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2018-03-01|title=Hawksbill sea turtle|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hawksbill_sea_turtle&oldid=828271087|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}{{Better source needed|reason=[[WP:CIRCULAR]]|date=August 2018}}</ref>
==Examples== The [[hawksbill turtle]] is one of the few animals known to feed primarily on sponges. It is the only known spongivorous reptile.<ref name="VDGIF">{{cite web | title =Species Booklet: Hawksbill sea turtle | work =Virginia Fish and Wildlife Information Service | publisher =Virginia Department of Game & Inland Fisheries | url =http://www.dgif.state.va.us/wildlife/species/display.asp?id=030073 | accessdate =2007-02-06 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20060924121429/http://www.dgif.state.va.us/wildlife/species/display.asp?id=030073 | archivedate =2006-09-24 | df = }}</ref> Sponges of various select species constitute up to 95% of the diets of [[Caribbean]] hawksbill turtle populations.<ref name="ScienceSpongi">{{cite journal | last =Meylan | first =Anne | title =Spongivory in Hawksbill Turtles: A Diet of Glass | journal =Science | volume =239 | issue =4838 | pages =393–395 | publisher =American Association for the Advancement of Science | date =1988-01-12 | doi = 10.1126/science.239.4838.393| id = | pmid =17836872 | jstor=1700236}}</ref>
''[[Pomacanthus imperator]]'', the emperor angelfish;<ref name="Angel1">{{cite journal | last =Thacker | first =Robert W. |author2=Mikel A. Becerro |author3=Wilfred A. Lumbang |author4=Valerie J. Paula | title =Allelopathic interactions between sponges on a tropical reef | journal =Ecology | volume =79 | issue =5 | pages =1740–1750 | publisher =Ecological Society of America | date =1997-08-19 | url =http://www.esajournals.org/esaonline/?request=get-abstract&issn=0012-9658&volume=79&issue=5&page=1740 | doi = 10.1890/0012-9658(1998)079[1740:AIBSOA]2.0.CO;2| id = | accessdate = 2007-02-16 | format = http://www.sciencemag.org/content/239/4838/393 – <sup>[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=author%3AThacker+intitle%3AAllelopathic+interactions+between+sponges+on+a+tropical+reef&as_publication=Ecology&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup> }} http://www.esajournals.org/doi/abs/10.1890/0012-9658(1998)079%5B1740:AIBSOA%5D2.0.CO;2</ref><ref name="Angel2">{{cite journal | last =Ferreira | first =C. E. L. | authorlink = |author2=S. R. Floeter |author3=J. L. Gasparini |author4=B. P. Ferreira |author5=J. C. Joyeux | title =Trophic structure patterns of Brazilian reef fishes: a latitudinal comparison | journal =Journal of Biogeography | volume =31 | issue =7 | pages =1093–1106 | publisher =Blackwell Publishing | year =2004 | url =http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1365-2699.2004.01044.x?journalCode=jbi | doi =10.1111/j.1365-2699.2004.01044.x | id = | accessdate = 2007-02-16 }}</ref> ''[[Lactophrys bicaudalis]]'', the spotted trunkfish;{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} and ''[[Stephanolepis hispidus]],'' the filefish{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} are known spongivorous coral reef fish.
Certain species of [[nudibranch]]s are known to feed selectively on specific species of sponges.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}
== Attacks and counter-attacks == [[File:Blue sponge at Coral Gardens Oudekraal DSC07978.JPG|thumb|257x257px|[[Turret sponge]], eaten by some spongivores.]] === Spongivore offense === The many defenses displayed by sponges means that their spongivores need to learn skills to overcome these defenses to obtain their food. These skills allow spongivores to increase their feeding and use of sponges. Spongivores have three primary strategies for dealing with sponge defenses: choice based on colour, able to handle secondary metabolites and brain development for memory. <ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Wulff|first=Janie L.|date=1994|title=Sponge Feeding by Caribbean angelfishes, trunkfishes and filefish|url=http://www.bio.fsu.edu/wulff/Wulff%201994a.pdf|journal=Sponges in Time and Space|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
Choice based on colour was involved based on which sponge the spongivore would choose to eat. A spongivore would bite small sample of sponges and if they were unharmed that they would continue eating that specific sponge and then move on to another sponge of the same colour. <ref name=":0" />
Spongivores have adopted to be able to handle the [[secondary metabolite]]s that sponges have. Therefore, spongivores are able to consume a variety of sponges without getting harmed. <ref name=":0" />
Spongivores also have enough brain development to be able to remember the same species of sponge it has eaten in the past and will continue to eat in the future. <ref name=":0" />
=== Sponge defense === [[File:Demospongiae morphology and spicule diversity.png |thumb|Sponge spicule]] A sponge defense is a [[Phenotypic trait|trait]] that increases a sponge [[Fitness (biology)|fitness]] when faced with a spongivore. This is measured relative to another sponge that lacks the defensive trait. Sponge
defenses increase survival and/or reproduction (fitness) of sponges under pressure of predation from spongivore. <ref>{{Cite journal|date=2018-03-08|title=Fitness (biology)|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Fitness_(biology)&oldid=829456081|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref>
The use of structural and chemical strategies found in sponges are used to deter predation. <ref name=":1">Hill, M., Lopez, N., & Young, K. (2005). Anti-predator defenses in western North Atlantic sponges with evidence of enhanced defense through interactions between spicules and chemicals. ''Marine Ecology Progress Series,'' ''291'', 93-102. doi:10.3354/meps291093</ref> One of the most common structural strategies that sponges have that prevents them from being consumed by predators is by having [[Sponge spicule|spicules]]. If a sponge contains spicules along with organic compounds, the likelihood of those sponges being consumed by spongivores decrease. <ref name=":1" />
Sponges have also developed [[aposematism]] to help avoid predation. Spongivores have learned four things about sponges aposematism and they are as follows: # If it is poison some predators will not eat it # If It is conspicuously coloured, or advertises itself by means of some other signals; # Some predators avoid attacking it because of its signals # These conspicuous signals provide better protection to the individual or to its genes than would other (e.g. cryptic) signals. <ref>Pawlik, J., Chanas, B., Toonen, R., & Fenical, W. (1995). Defenses of Caribbean sponges against predatory reef fish. I. Chemical deterrency. ''Marine Ecology Progress Series,'' ''127'', 183-194. doi:10.3354/meps127183</ref> Unfortunately, sponges that live in the deep sea are not at an advantage due to the colour because most colour in the deep sea is lost. <ref>Pinet, P. R. (2016). ''Invitation to oceanography''. Burlington, MA: Jones et Bartlett Learning.</ref>
== Impacts == Sponges play an important role in the benthic fauna throughout temperate, tropical and polar habitats. <ref name=":2">Bell, J. J. (2008). The functional roles of marine sponges. ''Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science,'' ''79''(3), 341-353. doi:10.1016/j.ecss.2008.05.002</ref> If there is a high volume of predation it can effect [[Bioerosion|bio erosion]], reef creation, multiple habitats, other species and help with the nitrogen levels.
Bio erosion that occurs in the production of reef sediments and the structural component of corals are partly produced by sponges, where solid carbonate is processed into smaller fragments and fine sediments. <ref name=":2" /> Sponges also play a role in increasing the survival of live coral on Caribbean reefs by binding fragments together and is expected to increase the rates of carbonate accretion. <ref name=":2" />
The coral reefs that contain higher amounts of sponges have better survival rate than the reefs with fewer sponges. Sponges can act as a stabilizer during storms as they help keep the reefs intact when presented with a strong currents. Sponges also grown between rocks and boulders, providing a more stable environment and lowering the disturbance levels. <ref name=":2" /> Sponges also provide habitats for other organisms to live in, without them, these organisms would not have a protected habitat.
Scientist have discovered that sponges play an important role in the nitrogen cycle. There are low amounts of nitrogen found in the water around coral reefs and most of the nitrogen that is found it bound into particulate or dissolved organic matter. Before this dissolved organic matter is able to be used by other reef organisms it must undergo a series of microbial transformations. <ref name=":2" /> The nitrogen cycle that occurs in sponges are able to cycle the nitrogen back into the water column and can be used by other organisms, especially the cyanobacteria.The cyanobacteria then can then fix the atmospheric nitrogen and then the sponges can use it. <ref name=":2" /> Therefore, if there is a high amount of spongivores present in an environment, it can effect other aspects of the environment besides sponges.

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[Image:Alois Riegl.jpg|thumb|[[Alois Riegl]], ca. 1890]] [[File:Relief plaque with confronted ibexes, Iran, Sasanian period, 5th or 6th century AD, stucco originally with polychrome painting - Cincinnati Art Museum - DSC03952.JPG|thumb|[[Confronted animals]], here [[ibex]]es, flank a [[Tree of Life]]. Iran, Sasanian period, 5th or 6th century AD, stucco originally with polychrome painting.]] '''''Stilfragen: Grundlegungen zu einer Geschichte der Ornamentik''''' is a book on the history of [[Ornament (architecture)|ornament]] by the Austrian [[art history|art historian]] [[Alois Riegl]]. It was published in [[Berlin]] in 1893. The English translation renders the title as ''Problems of style: foundations for a history of ornament'', although this has been criticized by some.{{efn|For example, Benjamin Binstock, "Alois Riegl, Monumental Ruin," in A. Riegl, ''Historical Grammar of the Visual Arts'' (New York, 2004), p.35 n.28: "Evelyn Kain's translation of what she strangely calls ''Problems of Style'' is unsatisfactory; it is not simply a question (or problem) of style." See also Kathryn Brush's review of the translation, ''Art Bulletin'' 74 (1994), p. 355: "Riegl wrote ''Stilfragen'', or ''Questions of style'' (curiously entitled ''Problems of Style'' in the 1992 English translation) during the 1890s...."}} It has been called "the one great book ever written about the history of ornament."<ref>E.H. Gombrich, ''The sense of order'' (London, 1984), 182.</ref>
Riegl wrote the ''Stilfragen'' while employed as director of the textile department at what was then the Österreichisches Museum für Kunst und Industrie (today the [[Museum für angewandte Kunst Wien|Museum für angewandte Kunst]]) in [[Vienna]]. His primary intention was to argue that it was possible to write a continuous history of ornament. This position is argued in explicit opposition to that of the "technical-materialist" school, according to which "all art forms were always the direct products of materials and techniques"<ref>''Problems of style'', tr. Kain, p. 4.</ref> and that ornamental "motifs originated spontaneously throughout the world at a number of different locations."<ref>''Problems of style'', tr. Kain, pp. 17-18.</ref> Riegl associates this view with the followers of [[Gottfried Semper]], who had advanced a related argument in his ''Der Stil in den technischen Künsten; oder praktischer Ästhetik'' (''Style in the technical arts; or practical [[aesthetics]]'', 1878-79). However, Riegl consistently disassociates Semper's followers from Semper himself, writing that
{{quote|The theory of the technical, materialist origin of the earliest ornaments is usually attributed to Gottfried Semper. This association is, however, no more justified than the one made between contemporary Darwinism and Darwin.<ref>''Problems of style'', tr. Kain, p. 4.</ref>}}
As the technical-materialist position had attained the status of dogma, Riegl stated that "the most pressing problem that confronts historians of the decorative arts today is to reintegrate the historical thread that has been served into a thousand pieces."<ref>''Problems of style'', tr. Kain, p. 12</ref> Accordingly, he argued for a continuous development of ornament from ancient Egyptian through Greek and Roman and up to early Islamic and, eventually, Ottoman art.
==Contents== [[File:Flickr - jemasmith - Umayyad Mosque, Damascus, Detail..jpg|thumb|Stone relief with [[Arabesque (Islamic art)|arabesques]] of tendrils, [[palmette]]s and half-palmettes in the [[Umayyad Mosque]], [[Damascus]]]] [[File:The 'Abraham of Kütahya' ewer dated 1510.jpg|thumb|right|'Abraham of Kütahya ewer', probably made in Kütahya, dated 1510. Ottoman [[İznik pottery]]]] The ''Stilfragen'' is divided into an introduction, which sets out the purpose of the work, and four chapters, each on a theme in the history of artistic style.
The first chapter, "The Geometric Style," argues that geometric ornament originated, not from such technical processes as wickerwork and weaving, but rather from an "immanent artistic drive, alert and restless for action, that human beings possessed long before they invented woven protective coverings for their bodies."<ref>''Problems of style'', tr. Kain, 30.</ref> He supported this position through an analysis of geometric ornament in [[Stone Age]] European art, in particular objects that had recently been discovered in the [[Dordogne]]. This ornament, he argued, developed from attempts to represent natural forms in two dimensions, which gave rise to the idea of an outline. After this "invention of line," the cave-dwellers proceeded to arrange lines "according to the principles of rhythm and symmetry."<ref>''Problems of style'', tr. Kain, 33.</ref>
The second chapter, "The Heraldic Style," addresses compositions of "paired animals arranged symmetrically to either side of an intervening central element."<ref>''Problems of style'', tr. Kain, 42.</ref> This type of decoration had been associated by previous scholars, most notably [[Ernst Curtius]], with the technical demands of [[silk]]-weaving. Riegl argued instead that heraldic ornament arose before the invention of mechanical weaving-looms, and stemmed from a desire for symmetry.
The third chapter, "The Introduction of Vegetal Ornament and the Development of the Ornamental Tendril," traces an unbroken evolution of vegetal ornament from ancient Egyptian through to late [[Roman art]]. Here Riegl argues that motifs such as the [[Nelumbo nucifera|lotus flower]], although they may originally have been endowed by the Egyptians with symbolic significance, were adopted by other cultures that "no longer understood their hieratic meaning,"<ref>''Problems of style'', tr. Kain, 50.</ref> and thereby became purely decorative. In the most famous section of this chapter, Riegl argued that [[Acanthus (ornament)|acanthus ornament]] was not derived from the [[Acanthus (genus)|acanthus plant]], as had been believed since the time of [[Vitruvius]], but was rather a sculptural adaptation of the [[palmette]] motif. It was therefore "a product of pure artistic invention,"<ref>''Problems of style'', tr. Kain, 200.</ref> and not of "a simple compulsion to make direct copies of living organisms."<ref>''Problems of style'', tr. Kain, 206.</ref>
The fourth chapter, "The [[Arabesque (Islamic art)|Arabesque]]," continues the development of the previous chapter through late antique and early [[Byzantine art|Byzantine]] and into [[Islamic art]]. The arabesque is understood here as a geometricized version of earlier systems of tendril ornament, thereby establishing a "genetic relationship between the ornamental Islamic tendril and its direct predecessor, the tendril ornament of antiquity."<ref>''Problems of style'', tr. Kain, 229.</ref>
The final two chapters are therefore presented as a continuous history of vegetal ornament from ancient Egypt through to Ottoman Turkey, in which individual motifs develop according to purely artistic criteria, and not through the intervention of technical or mimetic concerns. In the introduction it is suggested that this development could be continued to Riegl's own time, and that "ornament experiences the same continuous, coherent development that prevails in the art of all periods."<ref>''Problems of style'', tr. Kain, 9.</ref>
==Significance==
The ''Stilfragen'' remains a fundamental work in the history of ornament, and has heavily influenced the work of [[Paul Jacobsthal]] and [[Ernst Gombrich]], among others who have addressed the same themes.<ref>[[Jessica Rawson|Rawson, Jessica]], ''Chinese Ornament: The Lotus and the Dragon'', pp. 24-25, 1984, British Museum Publications, {{ISBN|0714114316}}. Rawson's Appendix, pp. 199-222, summarizes the early history of flower ornament around the Mediterranean: "Details of the present description differ from Riegl's analysis; however the general outline proposed follows his fascinating account" (p. 199)</ref>
Within Riegl's work as a whole, the ''Stilfragen'' constitutes his earliest general statement of principles, although his "theoretical thinking had not by any means reached maturity."<ref>Henri Zerner, "Preface," ''Problems of style'', xxii.</ref> By severing stylistic development from external influences, such as technical procedures or a desire to imitate nature, Riegl raised an extremely complicated set of questions regarding the actual source and significance of stylistic change. As [[Otto Pächt]] has written:
{{quote|In the picture that Riegl draws of the development the changes of style are meaningful in a specific way; continuity is not merely carrying on; every stylistic phase creates its own problems which are solved in the succeeding one, only to create new conflicts for which new answers have to be found. Thus the styles change of necessity, or to put it differently: in a kind of 'retrospective prophecy' the art historian shows that artistic development was compelled to move in the direction in which in fact it did. A view with most serious implications. One of them was that if one viewed art history in this way, absolute aesthetic norms became obsolete and had to be dropped.<ref>Otto Pächt, "Art historians and art critics, vi: Alois Riegl," ''The Burlington Magazine'' 105 (1963), 189.</ref>}}
Thus the concerns of the ''Stilfragen'' led directly into those of Riegl's next major study, the ''Spätrömische Kunstindustrie'' (''Late Roman art industry'', 1901), in which he approached style change in [[late antiquity]] not as a symptom of decline, but as the result of positive artistic concerns.
==See also== * [[Scroll (art)]] *[[Master of Animals]]
==Notes== {{notelist}}
==References== {{reflist|28em}}
==Editions and translations==
* German: ''Stilfragen: Grundlegungen zu einer Geschichte der Ornamentik''. First edition, Berlin, George Siemens, 1893. Second edition, Berlin, Richard Carl Schmidt, 1923. * English: Evelyn Kain, tr., ''Problems of style: foundations for a history of ornament''. Princeton, Princeton University, 1992. * French: Henri-Alexis Baatsch and Françoise Rolland, trs., ''Questions de style: fondements d'une histoire de l'ornementation''. Paris, Hazan, 2002. * Spanish: Federico Miguel Saller, tr. ''Problemas de estilo: Fundamentos para una historia de la ornamentación''. Barcelona, Gustavo Gili, 1980.
[[Category:1893 books]] [[Category:Art history books]]

revision.comment: /* Information technology */
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=February 2017}} {{undue|to=the subject's applications in the field of [[information technology]].|date=February 2017}} }} {{About|the interdisciplinary field|the analysis of systems in electrical engineering|system analysis}} The [[Merriam-Webster]] dictionary defines '''system analysis''' as "the process of studying a procedure or [[business]] in order to identify its goals and purposes and create [[system]]s and procedures that will achieve them in an efficient way". Another view sees system analysis as a [[problem-solving]] technique that breaks down a system into its component pieces for the purpose of the studying how well those component parts work and interact to accomplish their purpose.<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Systems-Analysis-Design-Global-Enterprise/dp/0071107665 System Analysis and Design for the Global Enterprise] by Lonnie D. Bentley p.160 7th edition</ref>
The field of system analysis relates closely to [[Requirement analysis|requirements analysis]] or to [[operations research]]. It is also "an explicit formal inquiry carried out to help a [[decision maker]] identify a better course of action and make a better decision than she might otherwise have made."<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070822025602/http://pespmc1.vub.ac.be/ASC/SYSTEM_ANALY.html SYSTEMS ANALYSIS]</ref>
The terms [[wiktionary:analysis|analysis]] and [[wiktionary:synthesis|synthesis]] stem from Greek, meaning "to take apart" and "to put together," respectively. These terms are used in many [[scientific discipline]]s, from mathematics and logic to economics and psychology, to denote similar investigative procedures. Analysis is defined as "the procedure by which we break down an intellectual or substantial whole into parts," while synthesis means "the procedure by which we combine separate elements or components in order to form a coherent whole." <ref>Tom Ritchey, [http://www.swemorph.com/pdf/anaeng-r.pdf Analysis and Synthesis.]</ref> System analysis researchers apply [[methodology]] to the systems involved, forming an overall picture.
System analysis is used in every field where something is developed. Analysis can also be a series of components that perform organic functions together, such as system engineering. [[System engineering]] is an [[interdisciplinary field]] of engineering that focuses on how complex engineering projects should be designed and managed.
==Information technology== The development of a computer-based information system includes a system analysis phase. This helps produce the [[data model]], a precursor to creating or enhancing a [[database]]. There are a number of different approaches to system analysis. When a computer-based information system is developed, system analysis (according to the [[Waterfall model]]) would constitute the following steps:
* The development of a feasibility study: determining whether a project is economically, socially, technologically and organizationally feasible * Fact-finding measures, designed to ascertain the requirements of the system's end-users (typically involving interviews, questionnaires, or visual observations of work on the existing system) * Gauging how the end-users would operate the system (in terms of general experience in using computer hardware or software), what the system would be used for and so on
Another view outlines a phased approach to the process. This approach breaks system analysis into 5 phases:
* Scope Definition: Clearly defined objectives and requirements necessary to meet a project's requirements as defined by its stakeholders * Problem analysis: the process of understanding problems and needs and arriving at solutions that meet them * Requirements analysis: determining the conditions that need to be met * Logical design: looking at the logical relationship among the objects * Decision analysis: making a final decision
[[Use case]]s are widely used system analysis modeling tools for identifying and expressing the functional requirements of a system. Each use case is a business scenario or event for which the system must provide a defined response. Use cases evolved from object-oriented analysis.
==Policy analysis== The discipline of what is today known as [[policy analysis]] originated from the application of system analysis when it was first instituted by United States [[Secretary of Defense]] [[Robert McNamara]].{{cn|date=April 2016}}
==Practitioners== Practitioners of system analysis are often called up to dissect systems that have grown haphazardly to determine the current components of the system. This was shown during the year 2000 re-engineering effort as business and manufacturing processes were examined as part of the [[Y2K]] automation upgrades.<ref>Géza HUSI: Mechatronics Control Systems</ref> Employment utilizing system analysis include [[system analyst]], [[business analyst]], [[Industrial engineering|manufacturing engineer]], [[system architect]], [[enterprise architect]], [[software architect]], etc.
While practitioners of system analysis can be called upon to create new systems, they often modify, expand or document existing systems ([[Process (engineering)|processes]], [[Procedure (term)|procedures]] and [[Methodology|methods]]). Researchers and practitioners rely on system analysis. Activity system analysis has been already applied to various research and practice studies including business management, educational reform, educational technology, etc.
==See also== {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ;Related topics *[[System thinking]] *[[System architecture]] *[[Software architecture]] *[[Enterprise architecture]] *[[Systems analyst]] *[[Systems design]] *[[Policy analysis]] *[[Program designer]] *[[Cybernetics]] *[[Systems theory]]
{{Col-break}} ;Types of system analysis *[[Accident analysis]] *[[Business analysis]] *[[Cost-effectiveness analysis]] / [[cost-benefit analysis]] *[[DSRP]] *[[Failure analysis]] *[[Logico-linguistic modeling]] *[[Morphological analysis (problem-solving)|Morphological analysis]] *[[Soft systems methodology]] *[[Software prototyping]] *[[Spiral model]] *[[Waterfall model]]
{{Col-break}} ;System thinkers *[[Donella Meadows]] *[[Nancy Leveson]] *[[Russell L. Ackoff]] *[[Howard T. Odum]] *[[Henry Paynter]] *[[Jay Forrester]] *[[Gregory Bateson]] *[[Stewart Brand]] *[[Buckminster Fuller]] *[[Robert S. McNamara]] *[[Stafford Beer]] *[[Ludwig von Bertalanffy]] {{col-end}}
==References== <references/>
== Selected publications == * [[Bentley, Lonnie D.]], [[Kevin C. Dittman]], and [[Jeffrey L. Whitten]]. ''System analysis and design methods.'' (1986, 1997, 2004). * [[Hawryszkiewycz, Igor T.]] ''Introduction to system analysis and design.'' Prentice Hall PTR, 1994. * [[Whitten, Jeffery L.]], [[Lonnie D. Bentley]], and Kevin C. Dittman. ''Fundamentals of system analysis and design methods.'' (2004).
==External links== {{commonscat}}{{Wiktionary}} *[http://www.cilco.co.uk/briefing-studies/index.html A useful set of guides and a case study about the practical application of business and system analysis methods] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110722022042/http://web.simmons.edu/~benoit/LIS486/SystemsAnalysis.html A comprehensive description of the discipline of system analysis from Simmons College, Boston, MA, USA (Archive of original from www.simmons.edu)] *[http://www.w3computing.com/systemsanalysis/ System Analysis and Design introductory level lessons]
{{Systems Engineering}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:System Analysis}} [[Category:Futurology]] [[Category:Financial analysts]] [[Category:Technology assessment]] [[Category:Systems analysis| ]]

revision.comment: /* External links */ lc
revision.text:
{{Infobox Journal | title = The Burlington Magazine | cover = [[File:The Burlington Magazine 1903.png|200px]] | editor = [[Jane Martineau]] | discipline = Art | abbreviation = Burlingt. Mag. | publisher = The Burlington Magazine Publications | country = | frequency = Monthly | history = 1903–present | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://www.burlington.org.uk | link1 = http://index.burlington.org.uk/about/3 | link1-name = Online index | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = 00076287 | OCLC = | LCCN = | CODEN = | ISSN = 0007-6287 | eISSN = }} '''''The Burlington Magazine''''' is a monthly publication that covers the [[fine art|fine]] and [[decorative arts]]. Established in 1903, it is the longest running art journal in the English language.<ref>T. Fawcett, 'Scholarly Journals', in: ''The Art Press – Two Centuries of Art Magazines'', London, 1976, pp. 3–10, {{ISBN|0-905309-00-6}}</ref> It has been published by a [[charitable organisation]] since 1986.
==History== The magazine was established in 1903 by a group of art historians and connoisseurs which included [[Roger Fry]], [[Herbert Horne]], [[Bernard Berenson]], and [[Charles Holmes]]. Its most esteemed editors <ref>H. Rees Leahy. 'For Connoisseurs: The Burlington Magazine', in: ''Art History and its institutions'', London and New York, 2002, pp. 231–245</ref> have been [[Roger Fry|Fry]] (1909–19), [[Herbert Read]] (1933–39), and [[Benedict Nicolson]] (1948–78). The journal's structure was loosely based on its contemporary British publication ''[[The Connoisseur (magazine)|The Connoisseur]]'', which was mainly aimed at collectors and had firm connections with the art trade. ''The Burlington Magazine'', however, added to this late [[Victorian era|Victorian]] tradition of market-based criticism new elements of historical research inspired by the leading academic German periodicals and thus created a formula that has remained almost intact to date: a combination of archival and formalist object-based art historical research juxtaposed to articles on collectors’ items and private collections, enlivened with notes on current art news, exhibitions and sales.<ref>A. Burton, 'Nineteenth Century Periodicals', in: ''The Art Press – Two Centuries of Art Magazines'', London, 1976, pp. 3–10, {{ISBN|0-905309-00-6}}</ref> The lavishness of this publication almost immediately created financial troubles and in January 1905<ref>Sutton, Denys, Select Chronology--'Letters of Roger Fry ' ,Chatto and Windus, London, 1972 {{ISBN|0701115998}}</ref> Fry embarked on an American tour to find sponsorship to assure the survival of the journal,<ref>C. J. Holmes, ''Self and partners (Mostly self)'', London, 1936, pp. 213–34, {{ISBN|1-4067-6927-4}}</ref> which he had quickly recognized as a magazine for the developing study of art history.<ref>Sutton, Denys Introduction-'Letters of Roger Fry', Chatto and Windus,London, 1972 {{ISBN|0701115998}}</ref>
==Content== From its first editorial, ''The Burlington Magazine'' presented itself as synthesising opposing traditions – historicist versus aestheticism and academic versus commercial – by defining itself an exponent of "Austere Epicureanism".<ref>Anonymous, ‘Editorial Article’, ''The Burlington Magazine'', 1 (March 1903), pp. 5–7</ref> Against the perceived "sameness" of the contemporary art panorama, ''The Burlington Magazine'' was to act as a disinterested guide, directing the public's attention to high-quality art on offer both on the market and on institutional settings and educating its readers on the elevating qualities of ancient art.<ref>A. Helmreich, ‘The Death of the Victorian Art Periodical’, ''Visual Resources'', 26, no. 3, (September 2010), pp. 242–253</ref> ''The Burlington Magazine'' editors and contributors were part of the institutional sphere of museums and academia and yet, unlike their German counterparts, they participated in the emerging world of the commercial galleries.<ref>T. Fawcett, 'Scholarly Journals', in: ''The Art Press – Two Centuries of Art Magazines'', London, 1976, pp. 3–10, {{ISBN|0-905309-00-6}}</ref> The magazine remained independent from any institution and yet it was instrumental in the establishment of academic art history in Britain: its [[dialectical]] dynamic between market and institution contributed to the creation of an original and multifaceted publication.<ref>B. Pezzini, 'An open resource for scholars and a primary source for research: the Burlington Magazine online index', ''Art Libraries Journal'',36, no. 3, (June 2011), pp.46–51</ref>
''The Burlington Magazine'' was founded as a journal of ancient art but already in its first decade, especially under the editorship of Fry articles on modern art became prominent. Topics covered in detail were: [[Paul Cézanne]] and [[Post-Impressionism]] in a debate between Fry and [[Dugald Sutherland MacColl|D. S. MacColl]],<ref>R. Shiff: ''Cézanne and the End of Impressionism'', Chicago, 1984, pp. 143–152</ref> a debate on a bust of Flora ascribed to [[Leonardo da Vinci]] and later discovered to be a forgery, and the role of archival research in the art historical reconstruction, with contributions by [[Herbert Horne]] and Constance Jocelyn Ffoulkes.
''The Burlington Magazine'', especially in its first decades, was also preoccupied with the definition and development of [[formal analysis]] and [[connoisseurship]] in the visual arts and consistently observed, reviewed and contributed to the body of attributions to various artists, notably [[Rembrandt]], [[Poussin]], and [[Caravaggio]].<ref>B. Nicolson, 'The Burlington Magazine', ''Connoisseur'', 191 (March 1976), pp. 180–183</ref> The journal had also many notable contributions by visual artists on other artists, notably [[Walter Sickert]] on [[Edgar Degas]].<ref>W. Sickert, 'Degas', ''The Burlington Magazine'', 31 (November 1917), pp. 193–191</ref>
==Production== The journal is published monthly, and features a cross-section of writers.
The first issues of ''The Burlington Magazine'' were printed on high-quality paper, had a typeface designed by Herbert Horne and were richly illustrated with black and white photographs, many by the arts and crafts photographer [[Emery Walker]].
== Editors == * [[Robert Dell]]: March–December 1903 * [[Charles Holmes]] and [[Robert Dell]]: January 1904–October 1906 * [[Charles Holmes]]: October 1906– September 1909 * [[Harold Child]] Assistant Editor with the advice of a Consultative Committee: October and November 1909 * [[Roger Fry]] and [[Lionel Cust]]: December 1909–December 1913 * [[Roger Fry]], [[Lionel Cust]], and [[More Adey]]: January 1914–May 1919 * [[John Hope-Johnstone (editor)|John Hope-Johnstone]]: July 1919–December 1920 * [[Robert R. Tatlock]]: Early 1921–1933 * [[Herbert Read]]: 1933–39 * [[Albert C. Sewter]]: 1939–40 * [[Tancred Borenius]]: 1940–44 * [[Edith Hoffmann]] (Assistant Editor who ran the Magazine with advice from Read): 1944–45 * [[Ellis Waterhouse]] acting editor (the magazine was officially without an editor): 1945–47 * [[Benedict Nicolson]]: 1947–July 1978 * Editorial Board of Directors: August–October 1978 * [[Terence Hodgkinson]]: November 1978–August 1981 * [[Neil MacGregor]]: September 1981–February 1987 * [[Caroline Elam]]: March 1987–July 2002 * [[Andrew Hopkins]]: August 2002–December 2002 * [[Richard Shone and Bart Cornelis (joint editors)]]: January 2003–March 2003 * [[Richard Shone]]: March 2003–September 2015 * [[Frances Spalding]]: September 2015–August 2017<ref>[http://www.burlington.org.uk/magazine/editors-of-the-burlington-maga Editors of ''The Burlington Magazine'' 1903–Present]</ref> * [[Jane Martineau]]: acting editor August 2017 to May 2017<ref>http://www.burlington.org.uk/about-us/staff-contacts</ref> * [[Michael Hall(art historian)|Michael Hall]]: May 2017 to present<ref>http://www.burlington.org.uk/about-us/staff-contacts</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://burlington.org.uk/media/_file/generic/michael-hall-appointment-press-release-2.pdf |title=Michael Hall appointed Editor of The Burlington Magazine |website=burlington.org |date=1 December 2016 |accessdate=5 July 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
